questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon aims to safely identify structures within the hepatobiliary triangle to avoid injury. Which of the following is not a boundary of hepatocystic triangle?
questions.solution:
Calot’s Triangle:

  • Bounded by the cystic duct (lateral), common hepatic duct (medial), and cystic artery(superior).
  • Contains the cystic artery, lymph nodes, and occasionally an accessory duct.
  • Identification of this triangle is crucial during cholecystectomy to avoid injury to the bile ducts or vasculature.

Hepatobiliary Triangle

  • Defined by the cystic duct, common hepatic duct, and an imaginary line running along the base of segment IV of the liver.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Cystic duct: Correct. It forms lateral boundaries of Calot’s triangle.

Option B. Common hepatic duct: Correct. This is medial boundary of Calot’s triangle.

Option C. Inferior border of the liver: Correct. It completes the third side of hepatocystic triangle.

Option D. Cystic artery: Incorrect. The cystic artery is usually located within hepatocystic triangle but does not form one of its boundaries.

Key Points:

Proper identification of structures within Calot's triangle is essential to prevent iatrogenic injury during gallbladder surgery.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presents with symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction, including persistent vomiting and upper abdominal pain. An endoscopic image reveals a large gallstone obstructing the duodenum. What clinical sign does this scenario describe?
questions.solution:
Bouveret’s Syndrome

  • Bouveret’s syndrome is a rare form of gallstone ileus where a large gallstone causes gastric outlet obstruction by lodging in the duodenum.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Symptoms include nausea, vomiting (often nonbilious), epigastric pain, and signs of dehydration.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging: Xrays may show air in the biliary tree (pneumobilia), a large radiopaque gallstone, and signs of gastric dilatation.
  • Endoscopy: Confirms the presence of a gallstone obstructing the pylorus or duodenum.
  • CT Scan: Provides detailed visualisation of the stone, fistula, and level of obstruction.

Management:

  • Endoscopic Removal: Attempted initially to extract the stone if feasible.
  • Surgical Intervention: Required if endoscopic management fails, typically involving removal of the stone and repair of the fistula.

Complications:

  • Perforation of the duodenum, persistent obstruction, and recurrent gallstone formation.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Courvoisier’s sign: Incorrect. Courvoisier’s sign refers to a palpable, nontender gallbladder in patients with jaundice, often due to malignancy.

Option B. Mirizzi’s syndrome: Incorrect. Mirizzi’s syndrome involves obstruction of the common hepatic duct due to a gallstone impacted in the cystic duct.

Option C. Bouveret’s syndrome: Correct. This syndrome is characterized by gastric outlet obstruction caused by a large gallstone passing into the duodenum

Option D. Gallstone ileus: Incorrect. Gallstone ileus typically causes obstruction in the ileum rather than at the level of the duodenum or stomach.

Key Points: Bouveret’s syndrome involves gastric outlet obstruction due to a gallstone lodged in the duodenum.

choices.text: Mild inflammation of the gallbladder without organ dysfunction
Severe inflammation with systemic organ dysfunction
Acute cholecystitis with associated gallbladder empyema

questions.text: According to the Tokyo Guidelines, acute cholecystitis is classified into different grades of severity. Which of the following statements accurately describes Grade III acute cholecystitis?
questions.solution:
Classification of Acute Cholecystitis (Tokyo Guidelines)


Explanation of Options:

Option A. Mild inflammation of the gallbladder without organ dysfunction: Incorrect. This describes Grade I (mild) acute cholecystitis.

Option B. Moderate inflammation with localized peritonitis: Incorrect. This describes Grade II (moderate) acute cholecystitis.

Option C. Severe inflammation with systemic organ dysfunction: Correct. Grade III acute cholecystitis involves severe inflammation and systemic complications such as cardiovascular, neurological, or respiratory dysfunction.

Option D. Acute cholecystitis with associated gallbladder empyema: Incorrect. While empyema may occur, it is not specific to Grade III.

Key Points:

  • The Tokyo Guidelines classify acute cholecystitis into three grades based on severity and organ dysfunction.
  • Grade III is characterized by systemic involvement and requires urgent medical and surgical management.

questions.text: A 70 year old patient presents with symptoms of bowel obstruction, including vomiting, abdominal distension, and absence of flatus. Imaging shows air in the biliary tree and an obstructing gallstone in the terminal ileum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gallstone Ileus

  • Intestinal obstruction caused by a gallstone.

Pathophysiology:

  • Stone enters the intestine through a cholecystoenteric fistula.
  • Obstruction usually occurs at the ileum.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Symptoms of bowel obstruction: vomiting, abdominal pain, distension, no flatus.
  • Imaging shows pneumobilia (air in the biliary tree) and a gallstone.

Diagnosis:

  • Confirmed with imaging: Xray or CT scan showing air in biliary tree and obstruction.

Management:

  • Surgery to remove the obstructing stone and repair the fistula. Supportive care to manage symptoms.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Gallstone ileus: Correct. This condition involves a gallstone causing intestinal obstruction, often indicated by pneumobilia and a visible stone on imaging.

Option B. Mirizzi’s syndrome: Incorrect. This condition involves common hepatic duct compression due to a cystic duct gallstone.

Option C. Biliary colic: Incorrect. Biliary colic is caused by temporary obstruction of the cystic duct, not intestinal obstruction.

Option D. Acute cholecystitis: Incorrect. Acute cholecystitis presents with localized right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis.

Key Points:

Gallstone ileus causes bowel obstruction due to a gallstone entering the intestine.

Treatment involves surgical removal of the stone and fistula repair.

questions.text: A 40 year old male with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with jaundice, fatigue, and right upper quadrant pain. Liver function tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin levels. Imaging reveals stricturing of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC)

  • Progressive biliary tract disease causing inflammation and destruction of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts, leading to fibrosis and cirrhosis.
  • Associations: Strong link with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), especially ulcerative colitis (80% of PSC cases have IBD).
  • Symptoms: Pruritus, fever, fatigue, right upper quadrant discomfort, jaundice, and weight loss.
  • Lab Findings: Cholestatic liver function tests with elevated ALP and GGTP; bilirubin can vary.
  • Diagnosis: MRCP/ERCP shows strictures and beading; liver biopsy confirms diagnosis ("onion skinning").
  • Treatment: Symptomatic relief with antibiotics, vitamin K, and cholestyramine. Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment for cirrhosis

Explanation:

Option A. Primary biliary cirrhosis: Incorrect. PBC primarily affects the small bile ducts and is associated with antimitochondrial antibodies.

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: Correct. PSC is characterized by chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease.

Option C. Choledocholithiasis: Incorrect. This condition involves gallstones in the common bile duct, causing obstruction.

Option D. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Incorrect. This cancer usually presents with a liver mass and elevated alpha fetoprotein, not bile duct strictures.

Key Points:

PSC is a chronic bile duct disease associated with ulcerative colitis. Management focuses on symptom relief and monitoring for complications.

questions.text: A 55 year old male presents with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever with chills. Physical examination shows hypotension and confusion. What do these findings suggest?
questions.solution:
Charcot’s Triad and Reynold’s Pentad

1. Charcot’s Triad:

  • Right upper quadrant pain, fever with chills, jaundice.
  • Classic sign of acute cholangitis.

2. Reynold’s Pentad:

  • Charcot’s triad plus hypotension and altered mental status.
  • Indicates severe cholangitis with systemic sepsis.

Clinical Significance:

  • Suggests biliary tract infection, often due to bile duct obstruction.Can lead to septic shock if untreated.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Acute pancreatitis: Incorrect. Acute pancreatitis presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back but does not typically cause jaundice or fever.

Option B. Biliary colic: Incorrect. Biliary colic involves intermittent pain without systemic signs like fever or hypotension.

Option C. Acute cholangitis with sepsis: Correct. Charcot’s triad (fever, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain) plus hypotension and confusion (Reynold’s pentad) indicate acute cholangitis with sepsis.

Option D. Gallstone ileus: Incorrect. This condition causes intestinal obstruction, not jaundice and fever.

Key Points:

Charcot’s triad indicates acute cholangitis; Reynold’s pentad suggests severe sepsis.

questions.text: A 60 year old woman undergoing imaging for unrelated abdominal pain is found to have calcification of the gallbladder wall. She denies any symptoms of gallbladder disease. What is the appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Porcelain Gallbladder

  • Gallbladder wall calcification.
  • Etiology: Chronic inflammation from gallstones leading to calcification.
  • Clinical Presentation: Often asymptomatic.May be found incidentally on imaging.

Diagnosis:

  • Detected on abdominal Xray, CT scan, or ultrasound as calcified gallbladder.

Management:

  • Elective cholecystectomy due to increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma.

Key Points:

  • Porcelain gallbladder is associated with a higher risk of cancer.

choices.text: Type I choledochal cyst; cyst excision with hepaticojejunostomy
Type II choledochal cyst; cyst aspiration
Type III choledochal cyst; endoscopic sphincterotomy
Type IV choledochal cyst; liver transplant

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging reveals a cystic dilation of the common bile duct. What is the most appropriate classification and treatment?
questions.solution:
Choledochal Cyst: Todani Classification and Treatment

Type I:

  • Fusiform dilation of the CBD.
  • Most common type.
  • Treatment: Excision and hepaticojejunostomy.

Type II:

  • CBD diverticulum.
  • Treatment: Excision of the diverticulum.

Type III:

  • Choledochocele, dilation at the duodenum.
  • Treatment: Endoscopic sphincterotomy.

Type IV:

  • Multiple cysts, both intrahepatic and extrahepatic.
  • Treatment: Cyst excision and biliary reconstruction.

Type V:

  • Caroli's disease (intrahepatic cysts).
  • Treatment: Varies, may include liver transplant in severe cases.

Key Points:

  • Choledochal cysts present with jaundice, pain, and mass.

choices.text: Type I Mirizzi's syndrome; laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Type II Mirizzi's syndrome; ERCP with stent placement
Type III Mirizzi's syndrome; open cholecystectomy with common bile duct exploration
Type IV Mirizzi's syndrome; liver resection

questions.text: A 65 year old patient presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and fever. Imaging reveals a large gallstone impacted in the cystic duct, common bile duct with large fistula formation. Which classification and treatment option are most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Mirizzi’s Syndrome – Classification and Treatment

  • Gallstone impaction in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck, causing common hepatic duct compression.

Classification:

  • Type I: External compression without fistula.
  • Type II: Small cholecystobiliary fistula.
  • Type III: Large cholecystobiliary fistula (>2 cm).
  • Type IV: Complete destruction of the common bile duct wall.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, fever.
  • May present with cholangitis.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging: Ultrasound, MRCP, or ERCP shows gallstone and ductal compression.
  • ERCP: Confirms fistula presence and location.

Management:

  • Type I: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
  • Type II-IV: Open cholecystectomy, bile duct exploration, and repair. May require biliary drainage procedures.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Type I Mirizzi’s syndrome; laparoscopic cholecystectomy: Incorrect. Type I involves external compression without fistula formation, managed laparoscopically, but this case involves a fistula.

Option B. Type II Mirizzi’s syndrome; ERCP with stent placement: Incorrect. ERCP may aid diagnosis, but surgery is often needed for fistulas.

Option C. Type III Mirizzi’s syndrome; open cholecystectomy with common bile duct exploration: Correct. Type III involves a large fistula and partial cholecystobiliary fistula, requiring open surgery for safe management.

Option D. Type IV Mirizzi’s syndrome; liver resection: Incorrect. Liver resection is not a standard treatment for Mirizzi’s syndrome.

Key Points:

  • Mirizzi’s syndrome involves cystic duct gallstones compressing the common hepatic duct.

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with painless jaundice and a palpable, nontender gallbladder. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with Courvoisier's law?
questions.solution:
Courvoisier’s Law

  • If a patient has jaundice and a palpable, nontender gallbladder, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones.
  • Gallstones cause chronic inflammation, leading to gallbladder fibrosis and contraction.
  • A palpable gallbladder suggests an obstruction without inflammation, often due to malignancy.
  • Exceptions:
  1. Double impaction simultaneously occluding the cystic duct & the distal CBD.
  2. Pancreatic calculus obstructing the ampulla of Vater.
  3. Oriental cholangiohepatitis (Ductal stones formed secondary to liver fluke infestation)
  4. Mirizzi syndrome

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Gallstone obstruction: Incorrect. Chronic inflammation due to gallstones usually leads to a contracted, nonpalpable gallbladder.

Option B. Pancreatic head cancer: Correct. Courvoisier’s law suggests that a palpable, non-tender gallbladder with jaundice is more likely due to malignant obstruction, such as pancreatic cancer.

Option C. Acute cholecystitis: Incorrect. This condition often presents with right upper quadrant pain and a tender gallbladder.

Option D. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Incorrect. This cancer primarily affects liver parenchyma and does not typically cause gallbladder distension.

Key Points:

  • Painless jaundice + palpable gallbladder → Unlikely gallstones.
  • Common cause: Malignancy (e.g., pancreatic cancer).

questions.text: A 45 year old woman presents with recurrent right upper quadrant pain. Imaging confirms the presence of gallstones. Which type of gallstone is most commonly associated with obesity and a Western diet?
questions.solution:
Types of Gallstones

Cholesterol Stones:

  • Composed mainly of cholesterol.
  • Common in obesity, high cholesterol, low fibre diet.
  • Yellow Green colour, often radiolucent on X Ray.

Pigment Stones:

  • Black Pigment Stones: Associated with chronic hemolysis (e.g., sickle cell anemia).
  • Brown Pigment Stones: Linked to biliary infection and stasis.

Mixed Stones:

  • Contain cholesterol, calcium salts, and bilirubin.
  • Form in conditions of altered bile composition and stasis

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Cholesterol stones: Correct. These stones are primarily made of cholesterol and are common in individuals with obesity, high cholesterol levels, and those consuming a Western diet.

Option B. Pigment stones: Incorrect. These stones are usually black or brown, often associated with hemolytic diseases or chronic biliary infection.

Option C. Mixed stones: Incorrect. While mixed stones contain cholesterol and calcium salts, they are less directly associated with obesity.

Option D. Calcium bilirubinate stones: Incorrect. These are a type of pigment stone, linked to infections or hemolysis.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and elevated liver enzymes. An ERCP is performed, and a filling defect is noted in the common bile duct consistent with a stone. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Choledocholithiasis and ERCP

  • Presence of one or more gallstones in the common bile duct, causing biliary obstruction.
  • Clinical Presentation: Jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes, possible fever and chills indicating cholangitis.
  • Diagnosis: Ultrasound: Initial imaging, may show dilated bile ducts.
  • ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): Gold standard for diagnosis and treatment, showing filling defects in the common bile duct.

Treatment:

  • ERCP with Stone Extraction: Firstline treatment to remove stones and relieve obstruction.
  • Cholecystectomy: Performed after ERCP to prevent recurrence, especially in patients with gallbladder stones.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Observation and follow-up: Incorrect. Choledocholithiasis requires active treatment due to the risk of complications like cholangitis and pancreatitis.

Option B. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: Incorrect. While this may be performed later, the immediate focus is on removing the common bile duct stone.

Option C. Endoscopic stone extraction: Correct. ERCP with endoscopic stone extraction is the treatment of choice for choledocholithiasis identified on ERCP.

Option D. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC): Incorrect. PTC is usually reserved for cases where ERCP is unsuccessful or not feasible.

Key Points:

  • ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic for choledocholithiasis. Cholecystectomy is recommended post ERCP to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with painless jaundice and weight loss. Imaging reveals a mass at the biliary confluence. Further assessment confirms it is hilar cholangiocarcinoma. According to the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) classification, the tumor involves the biliary confluence with unilateral extension to second-order biliary radicles and ipsilateral portal vein involvement. What is the correct T-stage of this tumor?
questions.solution:
T1: Tumor involving the biliary confluence without extension to second-order biliary radicles.

T2: Tumor involving the biliary confluence with unilateral extension to second-order biliary radicles and ipsilateral portal vein involvement or ipsilateral hepatic atrophy.

T3: Tumor involving the biliary confluence with bilateral extension to second-order biliary radicles; or unilateral extension with contralateral portal vein involvement; or main or bilateral portal venous involvement.

T4: Tumor invading adjacent organs.

Key Points:

  • MSKCC Classification: Determines tumor extent in hilar cholangiocarcinoma.
  • T2 Stage: Involvement of ipsilateral portal vein and second-order biliary radicles, often associated with hepatic atrophy.

choices.text: Always start dissection at the gallbladder fundus.
Begin dissection ventral and cephalad to the sulcus of Rouviere.
Divide the cystic duct blindly during difficult dissections.
Always convert to open surgery without attempting bailout techniques.

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon is finding it difficult to identify key anatomical structures due to dense adhesions around the hepatocystic triangle. The surgeon decides to use the B-SAFE method and applies the "time out" technique. Which of the following is part of the B-SAFE method during safe dissection in gallbladder surgery?
questions.solution:
B-SAFE Method in Gallbladder Surgery

B-SAFE Method: Uses five anatomical landmarks to guide safe dissection:

B: Bile duct

S: Sulcus of Rouvière

A: Hepatic artery

F: Umbilical fissure

E: Enteric (duodenum)

  • Safe Dissection Zone: Cephalad and ventral to the sulcus of Rouvière, extending to the umbilical fissure, avoids injury to the biliary structures.
  • Critical View of Safety (CVS): Conclusive identification of the cystic duct and cystic artery.
  • Bailout Techniques: Include fundus-first approach, conversion to open surgery, and subtotal cholecystectomy if dissection is unsafe

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Fundus-first approach is a bailout strategy but not the primary dissection method in most cases.

Option B) Correct. The B-SAFE method emphasizes starting dissection ventral and cephalad to the sulcus of Rouvière, which helps orient the surgeon and prevent injuries.

Option C) Incorrect. Blind division of the cystic duct can lead to bile duct injury, and it is not recommended.

Option D) Incorrect. Open conversion is one of the bailout techniques, but it should not be the first choice unless necessary.

Key Points:

B-SAFE Method: Prevents biliary injury by providing safe anatomical landmarks during difficult dissections.

choices.text: Normal gallbladder wall with no calcification

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed with asymptomatic gallstones during an abdominal ultrasound for routine health check-up. She has no history of abdominal pain, jaundice, or other related symptoms. Upon reviewing her medical history, it is noted that she is scheduled for a kidney transplant in the near future.Which of the following conditions would warrant a prophylactic cholecystectomy in this patient with asymptomatic gallstones?
questions.solution:
Prophylactic Cholecystectomy for Asymptomatic Gallstones

  • Indications for Prophylactic Cholecystectomy:
  • Large gallstones (>3 cm)
  • Choledocholithiasis
  • Chronic hemolytic conditions (e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis)
  • Gallbladder polyps >1 cm
  • Suspected malignancy (e.g., porcelain gallbladder, anomalous pancreatic duct drainage)
  • High-risk ethnic groups (e.g., Native Americans, parts of northern India)
  • Organ transplant patients (e.g., during kidney or liver transplantation)
  • Patients undergoing bariatric surgery

Porcelain Gallbladder: Calcification of the gallbladder wall, increasing the risk of gallbladder cancer, and warrants prophylactic cholecystectomy.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Gallstones less than 3 cm without symptoms do not typically warrant surgery unless other high-risk factors are present.

Option B) Incorrect. Asymptomatic gallstones generally do not require intervention unless there are associated risks, such as those listed in the indications.

Option C) Correct. Prophylactic cholecystectomy is indicated in patients undergoing organ transplants to prevent potential complications post-surgery.

Option D) Incorrect. Normal gallbladder wall without calcification does not indicate the need for a cholecystectomy unless other high-risk factors are present.

Key Points: Asymptomatic Gallstones: Typically do not require surgical intervention unless associated with certain risk factors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoes an abdominal ultrasound for evaluation of right upper quadrant pain. The patient is asymptomatic, and liver function tests are normal.What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Gallbladder Anomalies

  • Phrygian Cap:
    • A fold in the gallbladder fundus present in 5% of individuals. It is benign and requires no treatment unless symptomatic.
  • Floating Gallbladder:
    • The gallbladder may be suspended by a mesentery, making it prone to torsion, which is rare but can be life-threatening. Surgical intervention is indicated only in cases of torsion.
  • Absence of Cystic Duct:
    • Usually indicates a pathological condition, such as recent passage of a gallstone or a stone causing obstruction at the lower end of the cystic duct. Careful dissection is required during surgery to avoid injury to the bile ducts.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is not indicated unless the patient has symptomatic gallbladder disease or complications such as gallstones or cholecystitis.

Option B) Incorrect. Antibiotic therapy is not required for anatomical variations of the gallbladder like the Phrygian cap.

Option C) Correct. The Phrygian cap is a benign anatomical variant of the gallbladder where the fundus is folded over the body. It does not require any intervention in asymptomatic patients.

Option D) Incorrect. ERCP is used for biliary tree issues, particularly in cases of choledocholithiasis or obstructive jaundice, not for anatomical variations of the gallbladder.

Key Points:

  • Phrygian Cap: Benign variation; no treatment needed if asymptomatic.
  • Floating Gallbladder: Rare, risk of torsion.

choices.text: It is primarily used for the removal of common bile duct stones.
It can be performed even if the patient's coagulation parameters are abnormal.
It allows for drainage of intrahepatic bile ducts and biopsy of biliary strictures.
The contrast medium used is oil-based for optimal visualization.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of obstructive jaundice is admitted for further evaluation. An ERCP was attempted but failed due to an inaccessible stricture. The surgeon decides to perform a percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC). Which of the following is a correct statement regarding PTC?
questions.solution:
Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography (PTC)

  • Indication: Primarily for biliary drainage in cases where ERCP cannot access strictures, especially in the intrahepatic ducts.
  • Procedure: A slender Chiba or Okuda needle is introduced percutaneously into the liver, and entry into the bile duct is confirmed by contrast injection or bile aspiration.
  • Complications: Bleeding and bile leakage are potential complications, making normal coagulation parameters mandatory before the procedure.
  • Uses: Allows for external or internal biliary drainage, insertion of stents, and enables biopsy or stone removal through a choledochoscope.
  • Imaging: Under fluoroscopic or sonographic guidance, water-soluble contrast is injected to visualize the biliary system, demonstrating any strictures or obstructions.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. PTC is not primarily used for the removal of stones, but rather for drainage of intrahepatic ducts and evaluation of strictures, especially when ERCP fails.

Option B) Incorrect. PTC should only be performed after confirming normal coagulation parameters due to the invasive nature of the procedure.

Option C) Correct. PTC allows for both drainage of bile ducts and biopsy of strictures for cytological analysis. It also enables the placement of stents.

Option D) Incorrect. Water-soluble contrast medium is used for visualization, not oil-based.

Key Points:

  • PTC is a vital option when ERCP fails to access the stricture. Requires normal coagulation before the procedure.

questions.text: A 58 year old female undergoes cholecystectomy for chronic cholecystitis. The pathology report reveals gallbladder cancer confined to the mucosa (T1a) without nodal involvement or distant metastasis. What is the TNM stage of this cancer?
questions.solution:
TNM Staging for Gallbladder Cancer

Stage 0:

  • Carcinoma in situ (Tis); no invasion beyond the epithelium.

Stage I:

  • T1a: Tumor invades the lamina propria (mucosa).
  • T1b: Tumor invades the muscle layer.

Stage II:

  • Tumor invades perimuscular connective tissue without serosal invasion (T2).
  • No nodal involvement (N0) or distant metastasis (M0).

Stage III:

  • T3: Tumor perforates serosa or directly invades the liver/adjacent organ.
  • N1: Involvement of regional lymph nodes.
  • No distant metastasis (M0).

Stage IV:

  • T4: Tumor invades major blood vessels or multiple organs.
  • N2: Extensive regional lymph node involvement.
  • M1: Distant metastasis present.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Stage 0: Incorrect. Stage 0 represents carcinoma in situ (Tis), not applicable here as the tumor invades the mucosa (T1a).

Option B. Stage I: Correct. Stage I gallbladder cancer is confined to the mucosa or muscle layer (T1a or T1b) without nodal involvement or metastasis.

Option C. Stage II: Incorrect. Stage II involves invasion beyond the muscularis into the perimuscular connective tissue (T2).

Option D. Stage III: Incorrect. Stage III includes invasion into the serosa or directly into the liver and may involve regional lymph nodes.

Key Points:

Early Stage gallbladder cancer (Stage I) is limited to the mucosa or muscle and cholecystectomy is sufficient.

choices.text: Perform an urgent cholecystectomy within 72 hours

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. Ultrasound confirms a distended gallbladder with thickened walls and the presence of gallstones. There is no evidence of bile duct dilation. Her leukocyte count is elevated, and she is diagnosed with acute cholecystitis. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Acute Cholecystitis Treatment

  • Initial Management: IV fluids, antibiotics, and analgesia.
  • Definitive Management: Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy within 72 hours is recommended for most patients.
  • Percutaneous Cholecystostomy: Considered in high-risk surgical patients.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Broad-spectrum antibiotics can be started, but observation alone is insufficient for acute cholecystitis, as definitive treatment is required.

Option B) Correct. Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy (within 72 hours) is the treatment of choice for acute cholecystitis in most patients.

Option C) Incorrect. ERCP is not indicated unless there is evidence of choledocholithiasis or biliary obstruction.

Option D) Incorrect. Percutaneous cholecystostomy is reserved for critically ill patients who cannot undergo surgery.

Key Points:

Early cholecystectomy reduces complications and hospital stay. Antibiotics alone are not sufficient for definitive treatment.

choices.text: T-tube placement through the injury site
Conversion to open surgery without repair

questions.text: A 55-year-old female undergoes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, during which the surgeon suspects a bile duct injury. The injury involves less than 50% of the circumference of the bile duct, and the bile duct diameter is 4 mm. The surgeon plans for immediate management.Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Bile Duct Injury

  • Intraoperative Management: When bile duct injury is suspected, conversion to open surgery and intraoperative cholangiography are recommended to assess the injury extent.
  • Small Ducts (<3 mm):
    • Can be ligated if they drain only a single segment of the liver.
  • Moderate Injury:
    • T-tube placement is appropriate if the injury involves <50% of the duct circumference and duct size is >3 mm.
  • Extensive Injury:
    • Resection with Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy is required if thermal injury or circumferential injury is involved, or if the injury is near the hepatic duct bifurcation.
  • Thermal Injury: Always requires resection as damage can worsen over time.
  • Postoperative Imaging: ERCP or MRCP may be used postoperatively to assess biliary anatomy and rule out complications.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Ligation of the bile duct is appropriate only for ducts smaller than 3 mm, which drain a single segment of the liver.

Option B) Incorrect. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy is preferred when the injury involves more than 50% of the duct or in cases of significant damage near the hepatic duct bifurcation.

Option C) Correct. A T-tube placed through the bile duct allows healing in injuries that involve less than 50% of the duct circumference and ducts larger than 3 mm in diameter.

Option D) Incorrect. While conversion to open surgery can help manage the injury, repair with a T-tube is more appropriate in this scenario.

Key Points:

  • T-tube: Ideal for limited injuries where ductal continuity is preserved.Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy: Preferred in complex injuries involving major ducts or the hepatic bifurcation.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is in the ICU recovering from severe burns. He develops a fever of unknown origin and hypotension. Abdominal ultrasound shows thickening of the gallbladder wall and pericholecystic fluid. No gallstones are visualized. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Acute Acalculous Cholecystitis

  • Inflammation of the gallbladder without the presence of stones.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Old age, burns, trauma, total parenteral nutrition (TPN), immunosuppression, diabetes, critical illness.
  • Diagnosis: Thickened gallbladder wall, pericholecystic fluid on imaging, and clinical suspicion in critically ill patients. HIDA scan is diagnostic but not always necessary.
  • Management:
    • First-line in critically ill patients: Percutaneous cholecystostomy.
    • Definitive: Cholecystectomy once the patient is stable, if necessary.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Immediate cholecystectomy is not preferred in critically ill patients due to high mortality and morbidity risks.

Option B) Incorrect. Broad-spectrum antibiotics alone are insufficient for the management of acalculous cholecystitis.

Option C) Correct. Percutaneous cholecystostomy is often the first-line treatment in critically ill patients. It allows drainage of the gallbladder without the risks associated with surgery.

Option D) Incorrect. Although a HIDA scan can be diagnostic, percutaneous cholecystostomy is both diagnostic and therapeutic in critically ill patients.

Key Points:

  • Gallbladder ischemia and bile stasis are key pathophysiological contributors. Percutaneous cholecystostomy is preferred in critically ill patients to avoid surgery-related risks.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with episodic right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Ultrasound reveals no gallstones or sludge. A HIDA scan with CCK shows a gallbladder ejection fraction of 20%. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Biliary Dyskinesia

  • Functional disorder of the biliary tree due to gallbladder dysmotility.
  • Clinical Presentation: Similar to calculous biliary disease but without stones or sludge on imaging.
  • Diagnosis: CCK-stimulated HIDA scan: Gallbladder ejection fraction <33% is diagnostic.
  • Other causes (e.g., stones, malignancy) must be excluded first.
  • Management: Cholecystectomy is curative in most patients (>85%).
  • Complications: Persistent symptoms after surgery may require further evaluation (e.g., ERCP)

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Observation is not advised if the HIDA scan shows gallbladder dysfunction (low ejection fraction).

Option B) Correct. Cholecystectomy is recommended in patients with biliary dyskinesia, especially when symptoms are consistent with biliary pain and the ejection fraction is <33%.

Option C) Incorrect. ERCP with sphincterotomy is not the first-line treatment for biliary dyskinesia.

Option D) Incorrect. Repeat imaging is unnecessary if the diagnosis is confirmed.

Key Points:

Gallbladder dysmotility without stones causes biliary-type pain. Rome criteria help define biliary dyskinesia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of epigastric pain and elevated pancreatic enzymes. His liver function tests are normal. MRCP shows no gallstones, but there is dilation of the common bile duct. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sphincter of Oddi Dysfunction

  • Functional disorder of the sphincter of Oddi, causing impaired bile and pancreatic juice flow.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic pancreatitis, gallstones, previous biliary surgery.
  • Diagnosis:
    • MRCP: Ductal dilation without stones.
    • Sphincter manometry: Sphincter pressure >40 mm Hg predicts good response to therapy.
  • Management: Endoscopic sphincterotomy or transduodenal sphincteroplasty are effective

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Chronic pancreatitis typically presents with abnormal imaging findings (e.g., pancreatic calcifications).

Option B) Incorrect. Biliary dyskinesia affects the gallbladder, not the sphincter of Oddi.

Option C) Correct. Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction can cause recurrent biliary pain and ductal dilation without stones. It can lead to recurrent pancreatitis.

Option D) Incorrect. Primary sclerosing cholangitis typically shows a “beaded” appearance of the bile ducts on MRCP.

Key Points:

Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction leads to recurrent biliary pain and pancreatitis. Treatment is mainly endoscopic sphincterotomy or sphincteroplasty.

choices.text: Radiolucent fissures forming a tri-radiate pattern within a gallstone

questions.text: A 55-year-old male has a history of gallstones and underwent an abdominal X-ray, Which of the following radiological findings is referred to as the "Mercedes-Benz sign"?
questions.solution:
Gallstones and Mercedes-Benz Sign

  • Mercedes-Benz Sign: Refers to a tri-radiate lucency seen within a gallstone, representing trapped gas. Visible on abdominal X-ray.
  • Radiographic Features of Gallstones: Approximately 10-15% of gallstones are radio-opaque.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Air within the gallbladder is known as emphysematous cholecystitis, not the Mercedes-Benz sign.

Option B) Incorrect. Calcification on the edges of gallstones is not associated with the Mercedes-Benz sign.

Option C) Correct. The Mercedes-Benz sign refers to the tri-radiate radiolucent fissures seen within a gallstone on abdominal X-ray, caused by trapped nitrogen gas.

Option D) Incorrect. Air in the bile ducts is known as pneumobilia.

Key Points:

The Mercedes-Benz sign is specific for a gallstone with radiolucent fissures. Seen in chronic cases with gas accumulation in gallstones.

choices.text: Presence of dense adhesions between the gallbladder and surrounding structures
Thickened gallbladder wall with intramural nodules

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of right upper quadrant pain, weight loss, and jaundice. A CT scan reveals a thickened gallbladder wall with areas of heterogeneous enhancement. The surgeon suspects either xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis or gallbladder carcinoma.Which of the following features differentiates xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis from gallbladder carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Xanthogranulomatous Cholecystitis (XGC)

  • Rare chronic gallbladder inflammation, more common in females, seen in India and Japan.
  • Etiology: Bile extravasation due to rupture of Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses or mucosal ulceration.
  • Histopathology: Presence of lipid-laden macrophages (xanthoma cells), fibrosis, and inflammatory cells.
  • Imaging:
    • USG: Thickened gallbladder wall with intramural nodules; gallstones usually present.
    • CT: Hypoattenuating nodules, poor contrast enhancement, possible early liver enhancement.
    • Mimics: Gallbladder carcinoma due to liver extension
    • Diagnosis: Challenging; requires intraoperative frozen section to exclude cancer (2.3-13.3% risk).
    • Management: Open cholecystectomy preferred due to diagnostic difficulty and dense adhesions.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Dense adhesions can occur in both xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis and gallbladder carcinoma.

Option B) Incorrect. Gallbladder carcinoma can invade adjacent liver tissue, while xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis does not typically invade adjacent structures.

Option C) Correct. Lymph node enlargement is typically absent in xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis but can be present in gallbladder carcinoma.

Option D) Incorrect. Thickened gallbladder wall with nodules can be seen in both conditions.

Key Points:

  • XGC often mimics carcinoma radiologically but typically lacks lymph node involvement. Gallbladder carcinoma has a poor prognosis and often invades surrounding tissues.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for gallstones. Post-operatively, she notices bilious drainage from the surgical drain. According to the Strasberg classification, which type of bile duct injury is this?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Strasberg Classification is used to assess and classify bile duct injuries.
